Western blotting (WB) with antibodies against ubiquitin (Ub) and RIG-I was conducted. the cells with E2-GFP replication had much lower poly(IC)-induced IRF-3 phosphorylation, while the total IRF-3 level had minimal change. this result was consistent with the findings for X domain expression in HEK293 cells. both RIG-I and TBK-1 in S10-3 cells transfected with E2-GFP RNA had lower ubiquitination levels than control without HEV replication. results consistent with observation of PCP overexpression in HEK293T cells. endogenous TBK-1 in whole-cell lysate was also detectable. a model is proposed to illustrate the HEV inhibition in the RLR pathway of IFN induction. PCP mediates the deubiquitination of RIG-I and TBK-1. X domain inhibits IRF-3 phosphorylation. in our study, the HEV X domain was found to inhibit IRF-3 phosphorylation, which appears to be a new function for a viral macro domain. however, we were unable to detect interaction between the X domain and IRF-3 or the upstream kinase TBK-1 in IP experiments. thus, the mechanism through which the X domain inhibits IRF-3 phosphorylation needs to be further elucidated. the HEV Met-PCP polyprotein was found to act as a deubiquitinase for ubiquitin-, SUMO-, and ISG15-linked proteins in a cell-free system (35) however, Met-PCP was unable to cleave an LXGG motif, which should be recognized by cellular or viral PCP. the severe acute respiratory syndrome virus processes a papain-like cysteine protease capable of cleaving ubiquitin- and ISG15-conjugated proteins. targeting the viral cysteine protease with a virus-specific inhibitor blocks SARS virus replication while not affecting cellular deubiquitinases. this implies that the deubiquitinase function of viral PCP could be a potential therapeutic target.
